title: Navigating Stereotype Threats in Heading Recall Performance
text:
Collaborators: Cami Streuly, Shirley Du, and Cole Kaforey
Instructor: Abigail Noyce
This study examined whether gender stereotype threat influences memory performance in a heading-recall task. We collected data from 35 participants (1,400+ trials), cleaned the dataset in Excel, and analyzed it in Jamovi using ANOVA. Results were not statistically significant, but suggestive patterns emerged, indicating that stereotype threat may influence recall. Findings were presented as a poster at the CMU Department of Psychology undergraduate research session.

title: Investigating Relational Rule Learning
text:
Collaborators/Advisors: Julia Conti (graduate mentor) and Paulo Carvalho (PI)
This lab project studied how relational rule learning affects task mastery and whether prior rule-specific training or interleaved pretraining improve accuracy. Using participant data from OAK Lab, I applied multilevel modeling—learning the method as the project required—to analyze performance outcomes. Results showed that both prior training and interleaved pretraining influenced task accuracy, with effects varying by task difficulty.

title: Mapping Obesity: A County-Level Analysis of Lifestyle and Food Environment Factors
text:
Collaborators: Anvith Thumma and Jordan Faustin
This project examined county-level determinants of adult obesity in the U.S. using the 2025 County Health Rankings & Roadmaps dataset. We performed exploratory analyses (scatter plots, correlation matrices) and fitted a Huber regression model to identify predictors of regional variation in obesity rates. Findings revealed strong associations between obesity and both physical inactivity and food access, though results are correlational rather than causal. Results were presented as a poster and report during a Q&A session with UnitedHealth Group professionals and statistics faculty.

title: Predicting Flight Delays in Pittsburgh
text:
Collaborator: Emily Jiang
Instructor: Spencer Koerner
This class project developed machine learning models to predict flight delays at Pittsburgh International Airport. Using historical flight data from 2022–2023, we trained a random forest classifier to forecast 2024 delays. The final model achieved 78% prediction accuracy, demonstrating the practical application of machine learning techniques to transportation data. Findings were submitted as a written report.

title: Bookshelf
text:
Favorite Quotes

Favorite Books




































Favorite Comics
I’ve read a ton of X-Men over the years. Beyond the powers and fight scenes, what sticks with me is how it reflects real-world struggles faced by marginalized communities. I’ve always loved how Magneto and Professor X parallel Malcolm X and Martin Luther King Jr. That contrast in ideology makes the story hit harder. I love the series so much that I used to have a whole screenshot stash of the funniest X-Men moments, but it got lost somewhere along the way. So here’s to starting fresh and rebuilding the archive.

title: Impact of Incentives on Visual Search Performance
text:
Collaborators: Cami Streuly, Shirley Du, and Cole Kaforey
Instructor: Abigail Noyce
This project evaluated whether performance incentives improve efficiency in visual search tasks. Participants completed multiple search trials in Gorilla, and data were cleaned and analyzed in Jamovi using ANOVA. Results suggested modest effects of incentives, but findings were not statistically significant, likely due to the limited sample size. Results were submitted as a written paper.

title: Examining Gender Stereotype Threats on Academic Performance
text:
Collaborators: Amor Ai, Sisley Yang, Frank Janicke, Eesha Nagpal, and Camille Chandler
Instructor: Phoebe Lam
This project investigated the impact of gender stereotype threats on academic performance through a meta-analysis. We screened 117 studies, extracting effect sizes from 13 peer-reviewed articles, and synthesized the data in R. Results indicated that both affirmative and non-affirmative interventions improved performance compared to no intervention, though subgroup analyses were limited by small sample sizes. Findings were written up as a research report.

title: Exploring Mental Health Among COVID-19 Graduates
text:
Instructor: Roberto Vargas
This study compared mental health outcomes for undergraduates graduating during the COVID-19 pandemic’s peak (2020) versus its decline (2021). Using a publicly available dataset, I evaluated 100+ survey responses and applied PCA, logistic regression, and bootstrap sampling in R to build and validate predictive models. Results suggested that students graduating during the pandemic’s decline reported greater psychological distress than those graduating at its peak. Findings were compiled into a research report.

title: Statistical Insights into Medical Incident Records
text:
Collaborators: Emily Zhu, Sophia Mou, Alva He, Derek Gao, and Edward Brownhill
This project analyzed medical incident records for Mainstay Life Services, a nonprofit supporting individuals with intellectual disabilities and autism. We evaluated patterns in incident types, needs levels, and time-to-report using Fisher’s exact tests, time-series modeling, survival analysis, and Kruskal–Wallis tests. My primary contribution focused on medication error incidents, producing a detailed statistical report that was shared alongside a team presentation.

title: Helen Peng
text:
I’m a senior at Carnegie Mellon University, majoring in Statistics with a concentration in Psychology. I’m interested in using data to address real-world challenges, especially in public health and education. Currently, I’m part of the OAK Lab , where I investigate relational rule learning, how people learn and discover complex rules.
Outside of academics, I spend my free time exploring stories through books, TV shows, and media that reveal how people think, connect, and navigate the world. These stories are my favorite way to recharge and reflect, and you can find a few of them under the bookshelf tab.
